DOC.HEAD: Pro-Indian Tamils Ambush and Kill 18 Tamil Tigers
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Indian Tamil guerrillas ambushed and killed at least 18 members of the rival Tamil Tigers militia in northern Sri Lanka, residents said today. The attack in the Vavuniya district occurred Thursday night, barely 24 hours after the Tigers ambushed and killed 28 members of another Tamil band in the same area. Tamil residents in Vavuniya, 135 miles northeast of Colombo, said the People's Liberation Organization of Tamil Eelam attacked a Tiger patrol in Musalkutti southwest of Vavuniya on Thursday evening. The residents were contacted by telephone and spoke on condition of anonymity. On Wednesday, the Tigers ambushed two trucks carrying members of the Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front, killing 28 of them. Three Tigers also died in that battle just west of Vavuniya. The People's Liberation Organization of Tamil Eelam and the the Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front are allies in the struggle for power against the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the strongest Tamil militant group. The front won control of the provincial council a year ago in elections boycotted by the Tigers, who now are trying to dislodge the front and force new elections. The Tigers also have been battling the Indian peacekeeping force sent to Sri Lanka in July 1987 to disarm Tamil guerrillas who had been fighting Sri Lanka's Sinhalese-dominated government for a separate homeland in northeastern Sri Lanka. The two smaller Tamil groups agreed to give up armed struggle, but the Tigers refused to surrender their weapons an started attacking the Indian force. The Indians have been winding down their military presence and pulled out of the Vavuniya area today. They have withdrawn from six of the eight northeastern districts they once patrolled but remain in the major population centers of Trincomalee and Jaffna. The peacekeeping operation grew out of a July 1987 peace plan. The government of former Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said in September its troowould take longer. Indian Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral said the withdrawal should be over by March 31. Sri Lankan Foreign Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said today he had not been formally notified of India's new timetable. ``They (the Indians) appear to have decided on their own,'' Wijeratne said. He said he would have no further comment until he received a detailed report from the Sri Lankan Embassy in New Delhi. An estimated 25,000 Indian soldiers remain in Sri Lanka. India became involved because of the sympathies of its own politically powerful Tamil minority of 60 million from their fellow Tamils in Sri Lanka. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and say the Sinhalese majority discriminates against them. More than 11,000 people, including 1,100 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the northeast since the Tamil separatist revolt started in 1983. Six thousand have died in backlash by Sinhalese extremists in the Sinhalese heartland of central and southern Sri Lanka who accused the government of making too many concessions to the Tamils.
